Overview
The 2021 Australian Infrastructure Plan is a practical and actionable roadmap for infrastructure reform for
responding to the infrastructure challenges and opportunities identified in Infrastructure Australia’s 2019
Audit. Infrastructure Australia, an independent advisory agency, has applied best practice methodologies in
developing and assessing the proposed reforms in the 2021 plan. They include applying a theory of change
framework to ensure the recommendations follow a structured pathway to achieve Infrastructure Australia's
vision for 2036 to have infrastructure that improves the sustainability of the country’s economic, social,
environmental and governance settings, builds quality of life for all Australians, and is resilient to shocks and
emerging stresses. Multi-criteria analysis is used to articulate the trade-offs and implementation challenges
associated with the reforms. The 2021 Plan is supported by the 2021 Reform Priority List and 2021
Implementation Pathway to provide a detailed evidence-based plan for governments to implement reforms
that will create meaningful outcomes for all Australians.
Stakeholder engagement is a significant focus of the 2021 Australian Infrastructure Plan. Infrastructure
Australia engaged with more than 5,500 individuals, including domestic and global policy leaders, to test the
conclusions and identify reform opportunities. The plan has also been informed by an extensive sector-specific
engagement program that targeted industry experts, government, and academia. In addition, Infrastructure
Australia engaged extensively with stakeholders for the 2019 Audit and ran a formal stakeholder submissions
process for which they received 151 formal submissions from government, industry and academia, as well as
a small number of individuals. All this feedback was considered when developing the 2021 Plan.
